description: The Fall of Babylon (Revelation 17-18) presents an extended oracle against 'Babylon the Great, the mother of prostitutes and of the abominations of the earth.' The great prostitute sits on a scarlet beast with seven heads (identified as seven hills, suggesting Rome) and ten horns. She is drunk with the blood of the saints, yet her destruction comes suddenly. In chapter 18, heaven rejoices as Babylon burns - her merchants, sailors, and kings mourning while God's people are vindicated. This vision directly challenged Roman imperial claims while establishing a pattern for judging all idolatrous political-economic systems.
longDescription:
The Babylon vision spans two chapters, combining prophetic oracle forms with vivid symbolic imagery:

The Great Prostitute (17:1-6):
An angel shows John 'the great prostitute, who sits by many waters. With her the kings of the earth committed adultery, and the inhabitants of the earth were intoxicated with the wine of her adulteries.' She sits on a scarlet beast with seven heads and ten horns, covered with blasphemous names. She is dressed in purple and scarlet, glittering with gold, precious stones and pearls, holding a golden cup 'filled with abominable things.' On her forehead: 'BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF PROSTITUTES.' She is 'drunk with the blood of God's holy people.'

The Beast Explained (17:7-18):
The angel interprets the imagery: the beast 'once was, now is not, and yet will come up out of the Abyss' - a parody of God's eternal nature. The seven heads are 'seven hills on which the woman sits' (unmistakably suggesting Rome, built on seven hills) and also 'seven kings.' The ten horns are 'ten kings who have not yet received a kingdom.' They will ultimately destroy the prostitute herself.

Babylon's Fall Announced (18:1-8):
Another angel declares: 'Fallen! Fallen is Babylon the Great!' She had become 'a dwelling for demons' and 'a haunt for every impure spirit.' Kings, merchants, and sailors have grown rich from her luxuries. God's people are called: 'Come out of her, my people.' Her plagues come in a single day: 'death, mourning and famine. She will be consumed by fire.'

Lamentation of Kings, Merchants, Sailors (18:9-19):
Three groups mourn Babylon's destruction:
- Kings who 'committed adultery with her' stand far off, terrified
- Merchants weep because no one buys their cargoes anymore (the list of goods includes 'human beings sold as slaves')
- Sailors cry, 'Was there ever a city like this great city?'

Heaven Rejoices (18:20-24):
'Rejoice over her, you heavens! Rejoice, you people of God! You apostles and prophets! For God has judged her with the judgment she imposed on you.' A mighty angel throws a millstone into the sea: 'With such violence the great city of Babylon will be thrown down, never to be found again... In her was found the blood of prophets and of God's holy people.'
historicalContext:
The Babylon imagery draws on Old Testament oracles against the historical Babylon (Isaiah 13-14, 47; Jeremiah 50-51) while applying them to first-century Rome. The seven hills (17:9) unmistakably identify Rome, as ancient sources regularly called it 'the city on seven hills.' The prostitute imagery recalls prophetic language for unfaithful Jerusalem and pagan nations.

First-century readers would recognize the critique of Roman imperial power: economic exploitation (the cargo lists of chapter 18), religious syncretism (prostitution with 'kings of the earth'), and persecution of Christians ('drunk with the blood of God's holy people'). The vision assured persecuted believers that Rome's apparent invincibility was temporary.

The textual tradition is stable. The cargo list in 18:12-13 provides remarkable insight into ancient trade networks. The final phrase 'bodies and souls of human beings' (18:13) explicitly condemns Roman slavery.

Throughout history, interpreters have applied 'Babylon' to various powers: medieval Protestant reformers identified it with papal Rome; liberation theologians with oppressive capitalism; contemporary interpreters with globalized economic injustice. The symbol's power lies in its applicability to any system opposing God's purposes.
theologicalSignificance:
The Fall of Babylon establishes crucial theological truths:

1. Divine Judgment on Empire: Imperial power that claims divine prerogatives and persecutes God's people faces certain judgment. The vision relativizes all political power.

2. Economic Critique: The cargo list (18:12-13) condemns luxurious consumption built on exploitation, culminating in human trafficking. Economic injustice brings divine judgment.

3. Come Out: The call to 'Come out of her, my people' (18:4) demands social-economic separation from idolatrous systems. Christians cannot fully participate in exploitative economies.

4. Blood of the Saints: Babylon's primary crime is persecuting 'prophets and saints' (18:24). Martyrdom will be vindicated.

5. Sudden Reversal: Despite apparent invincibility, Babylon falls 'in a single hour' (18:10, 17, 19). Current power configurations are not permanent.

6. Heavenly Rejoicing: God's people are commanded to rejoice at Babylon's fall (18:20), affirming divine justice over evil systems.

keyPassages.text: The woman was dressed in purple and scarlet, and was glittering with gold, precious stones and pearls. She held a golden cup in her hand, filled with abominable things and the filth of her adulteries. The name written on her forehead was a mystery: BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF PROSTITUTES AND OF THE ABOMINATIONS OF THE EARTH.
keyPassages.significance: The great prostitute's luxurious appearance and identity

keyPassages.text: Fallen! Fallen is Babylon the Great! She has become a dwelling for demons and a haunt for every impure spirit. For all the nations have drunk the maddening wine of her adulteries. The kings of the earth committed adultery with her, and the merchants of the earth grew rich from her excessive luxuries.
Come out of her, my people, so that you will not share in her sins, so that you will not receive any of her plagues; for her sins are piled up to heaven, and God has remembered her crimes.
keyPassages.significance: The call to separation from idolatrous systems

keyPassages.text: Rejoice over her, you heavens! Rejoice, you people of God! You apostles and prophets! For God has judged her with the judgment she imposed on you.

comparativeNotes.oldTestamentOracles: Isaiah 13-14 and 47 contain oracles against Babylon. Jeremiah 50-51 provides extensive Babylon material that John draws upon (the cup of wrath, call to flee, sudden fall). Ezekiel's oracles against Tyre (Ezekiel 27-28) inform the merchant and shipping imagery.
comparativeNotes.romanContext: The seven hills identify Rome explicitly. The prostitute imagery contrasts with Roma Aeterna (Eternal Rome) propaganda. The cargo list reflects actual Roman luxury trade. Christians refusing emperor worship faced economic exclusion from trade guilds - real persecution informing the vision.
comparativeNotes.receptionHistory: Protestant Reformers identified Babylon with papal Rome. Liberation theology applies it to economic exploitation. Contemporary interpreters see it addressing globalized capitalism's injustices. The symbol's polyvalence allows application to any oppressive system, while its original Roman reference remains foundational.
